title: Kippah
text:
A kippah (; , plural ), also called a koppel ( ), or yarmulke ( ; ), is a brimless <a href="cap">cap</a>, usually made of cloth, traditionally worn by <a href="Jew">Jew</a>ish males to fulfill the customary requirement that the head be covered. It is worn by men in <a href="Orthodox%20Judaism">Orthodox</a> communities at all times. Among non-Orthodox communities, those who wear them customarily do so only during prayer, while attending a <a href="synagogue">synagogue</a>, or in other rituals. Most <a href="synagogue">synagogue</a>s and Jewish <a href="funeral%20parlor">funeral parlor</a>s keep a ready supply of "kippot".
Etymology.
The term "kippah" () literally means "dome", as the kippah is worn on the head like a dome. 
The <a href="Yiddish">Yiddish</a> term "yarmulke" is often associated with an <a href="Aramaic%20language">Aramaic</a> phrase (ירא מלכא) 'yireh malkha' meaning "fear of the King". It might be derived from Polish "jarmułka" or Ukrainian "yarmulka", perhaps ultimately from Medieval Latin "almutia" "cowl, hood" or of <a href="Turkic%20languages">Turkic</a> origin (akin to "yağmurluk", meaning "rainwear"), "Keppel" or "koppel" is another Yiddish term for the same thing.
Jewish law.
<a href="halakha">Halachic</a> authorities debate as to whether wearing a kippah at all times is required. According to the <a href="Maimonides">Rambam</a>, Jewish law dictates that a man is required to cover his head during prayer.
In non-Orthodox communities, some women also wear kippot, and people have different customs about when to wear a kippah- when eating, praying, studying Jewish texts, or entering a sacred space such as a synagogue or cemetery. The Reform movement has historically been opposed to wearing kippot, but in recent years it has become more common and accepted for Reform men and women to cover their heads during prayer and Jewish study.
However, according to several prominent authorities, the practice has since taken on the force of law because it is an expression of "yir'at Shamayim" (reverence for Heaven, i.e. God). The 17th-century authority Rabbi <a href="David%20HaLevi%20Segal">David HaLevi Segal</a> (The "Taz") holds that the reason is to enforce the Halakhic rule to avoid practices unique to gentiles. Since, he points out, Europeans are accustomed to go bare-headed, and their priests insist on officiating with bare heads, this constitutes a uniquely gentile practice, and therefore Jews would be prohibited from behaving similarly. Thefore he rules that wearing a kippah is required by <a href="Halakha">halacha</a>.
Other halachic authorities like Sephardi <a href="posek">posek</a>, the <a href="Chaim%20Joseph%20David%20Azulai">Chida</a> (Rabbi Chaim David Yosef Azulai), hold that wearing a head covering is a "midat hasidut", an additional measure of piety. In a recent responsum, former Sephardic Chief Rabbi of Israel <a href="Ovadia%20Yosef">Ovadia Yosef</a> ruled that it should be worn to show affiliation with the religiously observant community.
The <a href="Talmud">Talmud</a> states, "Cover your head in order that the fear of heaven may be upon you." Rabbi Hunah ben Joshua never walked 4 <a href="cubits">cubits</a> (6.6 feet, or 2 meters) with his head uncovered. He explained: "Because the <a href="Shekhinah">Divine Presence</a> is always over my head." This was understood by Rabbi Yosef Karo in the <a href="Shulchan%20Arukh">Shulchan Arukh</a> as indicating that Jewish men should cover their heads, and should not walk more than four cubits bareheaded. Covering one's head, such as by wearing a kippah, is described as "honoring God". The "<a href="Mishnah%20Berurah">Mishnah Berurah</a>" modifies this ruling, adding that the "<a href="Achronim">Achronim</a>" established a requirement to wear a head covering even when traversing fewer than four cubits, and even when one is standing still, indoors and outside. "<a href="Kitzur%20Shulchan%20Aruch%20%28book%29">Kitzur Shulchan Aruch</a>" cites a story from the Talmud (Shabbat 156b) about <a href="Rav%20Nachman%20bar%20Yitzchak">Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak</a>, who might have become a thief had his mother not saved him from this fate by insisting that he cover his head, which instilled in him the fear of God. In Orthodox communities, boys are encouraged to wear a "kippah" from a young age in order to ingrain the habit.
The Talmud implies that unmarried men did not wear a kippah:
The Tanakh implies that covering one's head is a sign of mourning:
The argument for the kippa has two sides. The <a href="Vilna%20Gaon">Vilna Gaon</a> said one can make a "<a href="berakhah">berakhah</a>" without a kippah, since wearing a kippah is only a "midos chassidus" ("exemplary attribute"). In the 21st century, there has been an effort to suppress earlier sources that practiced this leniency, including erasing lenient <a href="responsa">responsa</a> from newly published books. <a href="Isaac%20ben%20Moses%20of%20Vienna">Or Zarua</a> (13th century) wrote that "our rabbis in France" customarily made blessings while bareheaded, but he criticized this practice.
According to 20th-century Rabbi <a href="Isaac%20Klein">Isaac Klein</a>, a Conservative Jew ought to cover his head when in the synagogue, at prayer or sacred study, when engaging in a ritual act, and when eating. In the mid-19th century, Reformers led by <a href="Isaac%20Mayer%20Wise">Isaac Wise</a> completely rejected the "kippot" after an altercation in which Rabbi Wise's kippah was knocked off his head. Nowadays, almost all Conservative synagogues require men to wear a head covering (usually a "kippah"), but in Reform synagogues, there is no requirement. However, "kippot" may be provided to anybody who wishes to wear them.
Types and variation.
In the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> in Europe, the distinctive Jewish headgear was the <a href="Jewish%20hat">Jewish hat</a>, a full hat with a brim and a central point or stalk. Originally used by choice among Jews to distinguish themselves, it was later made compulsory by Christian governments in some places as a discriminatory measure. In the early 19th century in the United States, rabbis often wore a scholar's cap (large saucer-shaped caps of cloth, like a beret) or a Chinese skullcap. Other Jews of this era wore black pillbox-shaped "kippot".
Often, the color and fabric of the "kippah" can be a sign of adherence to a specific religious movement, particularly in Israel. <a href="Knit">Knit</a>ted or <a href="crochet">crochet</a>ed "kippot", known as "kippot serugot", are usually worn by <a href="Religious%20Zionist%20movement">Religious Zionists</a> and the <a href="Modern%20Orthodox%20Judaism">Modern Orthodox</a>. They also wear suede or leather "kippot". Knitted "kippot" were first made in the late 1940s, and became popular after being worn by Rabbi <a href="Moshe-Zvi%20Neria">Moshe-Zvi Neria</a>. Members of most <a href="Haredi%20Judaism">Haredi</a> groups wear black velvet or cloth "kippot".
More recently, "kippot" have been observed made in the colors of sports teams, especially <a href="football">football</a>. In the United States, children's "kippot" featuring cartoon characters or themes such as "<a href="Star%20Wars">Star Wars</a>" are popular. (In response to this trend, some Jewish schools have banned "kippot" with characters that do not conform to traditional Jewish values.) "Kippot" have been inscribed on the inside as a souvenir for a celebration ("bar/bat mitzvah" or wedding). "Kippot" for women are also being made and worn. These are sometimes made of beaded wire to seem more feminine. A special baby kippah has two strings on each side to fasten it and is often used in a "<a href="brit%20milah">brit milah</a>" ceremony.
Head coverings in ancient Israelite culture.
The <a href="Israelites">Israelites</a> on <a href="Sennacherib">Sennacherib</a>'s <a href="Lachish%20reliefs">marble relief</a> appear with headdress. The ambassadors of <a href="Jehu">Jehu</a> on the <a href="Black%20Obelisk%20of%20Shalmaneser%20III">Shalmaneser stele</a> have head coverings, and their costume seems to be Israelite. One passage of the older literature is of significance: I Kings 20:31 mentions חֲבָליִם "havalim", which are placed around the head. This suggests portrayals of <a href="Demographics%20of%20Syria">Syrians</a> on <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>ian monuments, represented wearing a cord around their long, flowing hair, a custom still followed in <a href="Arabia">Arabia</a>.
Evidently the costume of the poorest classes is represented; but as the cord gave no protection against the heat of the sun, there is little probability that the custom lasted very long. Much more common was the simple cloth skullcap, dating to Egyptian times. Persons of high society routinely shaved their heads, to prevent <a href="lice">lice</a>. Conversely, their skullcaps also served as protection against irritation from their wigs.
The Israelites might have worn a headdress similar to that worn by the <a href="Bedouins">Bedouins</a>, but it is unknown whether a fixed type of headdress was used. That the headdress of the Israelites might have been in the "fellah" style may be inferred from the use of the noun צַנִיף "tzanif" (the verb "tzanaf" meaning "to roll like a ball", Isaiah 22:18) and by the verb חַבָּש "habash" ("to wind", comp. Ezekiel 16:10; Jonah 2:6). As to the form of such turbans, nothing is known, and they may have varied according to the different classes of society. This was customary with the Assyrians and Babylonians, for example, whose fashions likely influenced the costume of the Israelites—particularly during and after the <a href="Babylonian%20captivity">Babylonian Exile</a>. In Yemen, the wrap around the cap was called מַצַר "matzar"; the head covering worn by women was a גַּרגוּש "<a href="gargush">gargush</a>".
Civil legal issues.
In "<a href="Goldman%20v.%20Weinberger">Goldman v. Weinberger</a>", 475 U.S. 503 (1986), the <a href="United%20States%20Supreme%20Court">United States Supreme Court</a> ruled in a 5–4 decision that active military members were required to remove the yarmulke indoors, citing uniform regulations that state only armed security police may keep their heads covered while indoors.
Congress passed the Religious Apparel Amendment after a war story from the <a href="1983%20Beirut%20barracks%20bombing">1983 Beirut barracks bombing</a> about the "camouflage kippah" of Jewish Navy Chaplain <a href="Arnold%20Resnicoff">Arnold Resnicoff</a> was read into the "Congressional Record". Catholic Chaplain George Pucciarelli tore off a piece of his <a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Corps">Marine Corps</a> uniform to replace Resnicoff's "kippah" when it had become blood-soaked after being used to wipe the faces of wounded Marines after the 1983 Beirut barracks bombing. This amendment was eventually incorporated into U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) regulations on the "Accommodation of Religious Practices Within the Military Services".
This story of the "camouflage kippah" was re-told at many levels, including a keynote speech by President <a href="Ronald%20Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> to the Baptist Fundamentalism Annual Convention in 1984, and another time during a <a href="White%20House">White House</a> meeting between Reagan and the American Friends of Lubavitch. After recounting the Beirut story, Reagan asked them about the religious meaning of the kippah. Rabbi <a href="Abraham%20Shemtov">Abraham Shemtov</a>, the leader of the group, responded: "Mr. President, the kippah to us is a sign of reverence." Rabbi Feller, another member of the group, continued: "We place the kippah on the very highest point of our being—on our head, the vessel of our intellect—to tell ourselves and the world that there is something which is above man's intellect: the infinite Wisdom of God."
Passage of the Religious Apparel Amendment and the subsequent DOD regulations were followed in 1997 by the passing of the <a href="Religious%20Freedom%20Restoration%20Act">Religious Freedom Restoration Act</a> (RFRA). However, the Supreme Court struck down RFRA as beyond Congress' powers to bind the states in the 1997 case "<a href="City%20of%20Boerne%20v.%20Flores">City of Boerne v. Flores</a>". RFRA is constitutional as applied to the Federal government, as seen in "<a href="Gonzales%20v.%20O%20Centro%20Espirita%20Beneficente%20Uniao%20do%20Vegetal">Gonzales v. O Centro Espirita Beneficente Uniao do Vegetal</a>".
The <a href="Religious%20Land%20Use%20and%20Institutionalized%20Persons%20Act">Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act</a> of 2000 (RLUIPA), 114 Stat. 804, 42 U. S. C. §2000cc-1(a)(1)-(2), upheld as constitutional in "<a href="Cutter%20v.%20Wilkinson">Cutter v. Wilkinson</a>", 44 U.S. 709 (2005), requires by inference that Orthodox Jewish prisoners be reasonably accommodated in their request to wear yarmulkas.
The French government <a href="French%20law%20on%20secularity%20and%20conspicuous%20religious%20symbols%20in%20schools">banned the wearing</a> of "kippot", "<a href="hijab">hijab</a>s", and large <a href="Christian%20cross">crosses</a> in public primary and secondary schools in France in March 2004.
The provincial government of <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>, Canada passed "An Act respecting the laicity of the State" in June 2019, which prohibits the wearing of "religious symbols" by government employees including teachers, police officers, judges, prosecutors, and members of certain commissions.
Wearing by non-Jews.
Though it is not required, when a non-Jew wears a kippah in a synagogue, it is considered a sign of respect. Yarmulkes are often provided to guests at a <a href="Bar%20or%20Bat%20Mitzvah">Bar or Bat Mitzvah</a>. They are also often provided at <a href="Bereavement%20in%20Judaism">bereavement</a> events and at <a href="Jewish%20cemetery">Jewish cemeteries</a>. According to the Conservative <a href="Committee%20on%20Jewish%20Law%20and%20Standards">Committee on Jewish Law and Standards</a>, there is no <a href="halakhic">halakhic</a> reason to require a non-Jew to cover his head, but it is recommended that non-Jews be asked to wear a kippah where ritual or worship is being conducted, both out of respect for the Jewish congregation and as a gesture of respectfully including the non-Jewish guest.
Kippot were adopted as a symbol by some of the non-Jewish African American marchers in the 1965 <a href="Selma%20to%20Montgomery%20marches">Selma to Montgomery marches</a>, most prominently by <a href="James%20Bevel">James Bevel</a>.
